post_text:
Huge shout out to our ğŸ‘ parents at Murray School District... you are a driving force behind some of the successes we are experiencing in our schools. There's always room for improvement, but students are doing great with their distancing and mask-wearing protocols. Keep it up! Keep encouraging. Keep reminding! And when they are sick, please, please, please keep them at home to keep others safe.

These protocols flat out work and we are seeing evidence of that through week 4 of the school year.

#wearemurray #LearningWithCARE

post_text:
MCSD families, as of right now we are still planning for a normal school day tomorrow. However, we will continue to monitor conditions as we recognize there were several schools in other districts without power this morning which necessitated a change in plans. For now, be safe and weâ€™ll keep you posted across our multiple channels of information (Facebook, ParentSquare, and by phone).

If you havenâ€™t already, this is a perfect time to remind you to ensure your contact information is updated in our Aspire database so that we can notify you of changes and important information. Go here to verify your information: https://sisweb.murrayschools.org/Login/

Finally, BIG Shout Out to Murray City Power for keep the lights on at our schools today!

#wearemurray #LearningWithCARE

This new program begins September 14, however families who have paid for school lunch and/or breakfast from September 1st to 14th will be ğŸ’µ credited in their accounts.

post_text:
Last week, the Murray School District Board of Education approved some adjustments to the schedule for the 2020-21 school year, per directives given by the Utah State Board of Education in dealing with the global pandemic. These provide our teachers with additional professional development hours that MCSD will use at the end of each term. Most notably, the last day of school for this academic year has been moved up to May 28.

Go here to download the revised schedule:
https://www.murrayschools.org/school-year-calendar/

#wearemurray #LearningWithCARE

ğŸ¤“Working with Murray City School District, Friends of Sight is providing free ğŸ‘¨â€âš•ï¸ eye exams and ğŸ‘“ glasses to qualified, low income children.

ğŸ‘‰If your child needs a full eye exam or has had glasses in the past and needs a new pair, call your health plan for a list of participating providers and benefit information. Most insurance medical plans provide eye exam coverage.

ğŸ“ŒIf your child does NOT have medical insurance (including Medicaid) and is eligible for the free or reduced school lunch program, call Natalee at Friends for Sight, 801-524-2020, or email vision@friendsforsight.org. They have programs in place for free eye exams & glasses. They can also help children and adults in need of replacement/broken glasses who have a valid prescription.

https://www.murrayschools.org/friends-for-sight/

#wearemurray #LearningWithCARE

post_text:
Now that Online-Only registration is complete, we are focusing on the remainder of those who need to register for in-class/hybrid option school.

We would ask that you complete that process no later than August 7, 2020.

To register your student, please go to www.murrayschools.org, click on parents, and then click on registration materials.

If you have any questions, please call the school where your student will be attending.

post_text:
All students should have equal access to education - to connect with a teacher that can guide, mentor, and shape their future. In Murray, we are moving closer and closer to fully bridging the digital divide the separates some of our students. But this step also means giving all of our students a dedicated access point, uninterrupted by other family use of technology in the home... in other words, THIS IS A VERY BIG DEAL, and MCSD is the FIRST IN THE ENTIRE COUNTRY to do it!

On a somewhat related note, while there is still time to register for our in-class and hybrid learning options, our online-only learning option is rapidly approaching the August 4 deadline. Go to murrayschools.org and click Student Registration at the top to begin that process.

#wearemurray #returningwithcare
https://kutv.com/news/coronavirus/murray-city-school-district-to-debut-first-in-nation-internet-plan-for-students

WHAT'S TODAYğŸ“†
National Chicken Wing Day!

ğŸ‘‰Chicken wings have been around since, wellâ€¦ the ğŸ”chicken! But the concept of cooking wings in peppery hot sauce was born in 1964 at the Anchor Bar in Buffalo, New York, when co-owner Teressa Bellissimo cooked leftover wings in hot sauce as a late-night snack for her son and his friends. The guys liked them so much that the Bellissimos put them on the menu the next day. Served with celery slices and bleu cheese sauce, â€œBuffalo Wingsâ€ were an instant hit and today they are popular all over the US and other countries.ğŸ˜

What sauce do you like to dip your wings in?
ğŸ” A. Ranch
ğŸ” B. Bleu Cheese
ğŸ” C. BBQ
ğŸ” D. Other/Specify

#wearemurray

But the concept of cooking wings in peppery hot sauce was born in 1964 at the Anchor Bar in Buffalo, New York, when co-owner Teressa Bellissimo cooked leftover wings in hot sauce as a late-night snack for her son and his friends. The guys liked them so much that the Bellissimos put them on the menu the next day. Served with celery slices and bleu cheese sauce, â€œBuffalo Wingsâ€ were an instant hit and today they are popular all over the US and other countries.ğŸ˜

What sauce do you like to dip your wings in?
ğŸ” A. Ranch
ğŸ” B. Bleu Cheese
ğŸ” C. BBQ
ğŸ” D. Other/Specify

#wearemurray

WHAT'S TODAYğŸ“†
More than 200,000 phone calls are placed to domestic violence hotlines every year. No one should experience abuse. So today is National Love is Kindness Day â€“ a day recognize freedom from abuse. Along with sharing this post, here are things you can do today...

ğŸ‘‰ Celebrate for all victims of domestic violence/domestic abuse their FREEDOM and INDEPENDENCE from their abuser.
ğŸ‘‰ Recognize our right to be treated with KINDNESS. Because real love is kind, not terrorizing.
ğŸ‘‰ Realize that kindness is the path to healthy and safer relationships, families, society, and world.
ğŸ‘‰ Give voice for and hope and support to others who are still suffering, often in silence.
ğŸ‘‰ Spread messages how we can be kind to one another, especially to those closest to us.
ğŸ‘‰ Remember that love is not abusive, violent, demeaning or dehumanizing. If someone uses love as an excuse for their hurtful behavior, itâ€™s not real love.

#wearemurray

post_text:
Happy Pioneer Day! Here are three quick facts you may not have known:
ğŸ‘‰The 1847 pioneers came in on wagons, not handcarts. Handcarts came about 10 years later.
ğŸ‘‰As Brigham Young entered the Salt Lake Valley, he was actually quite sick and surveyed the land from a bed in his wagon.
ğŸ‘‰The first celebration of Pioneer Day didn't occur until 1857.

WHAT'S TODAYğŸ“†
We love celebrating diversity ğŸ¥° and things that make us all unique. For some thatâ€™s having eyes ğŸ‘€ with different colors for each â€“ this is called heterochromia.

For some, this condition has no impact and for others, there can be some complications. But as we love all peopleğŸ˜, we celebrate the uniqueness we each have to offer in life and this is certainly not something you see every day. A few celebrities are known to have two different colored eyes include David Bowie, Christopher Walken, Dan Aykroyd, Jane Seymour, and Mila Kunis.

#wearemurray

Well, today has traditionally been 7/11 Day â€“ a day to go get a free Slurpee ğŸ¥¤, but with that cancelled hereâ€™s an alternative that is still pretty cool and definitely will make you feel good inside. Today is cheer up the lonely day! ğŸ¥°

There are LOTS of lonely people out there right now ğŸ˜” â€“ and kids have the ability to lift the spirits of lonely people. So make a call, send an email, or mail a card to the lonely person you are thinking of. Let them know you care.

This is something we can all take five minutes âŒšï¸to do and great to explain to our kids we donâ€™t always need a holiday or vacation to express love to someone who is lonely â€“ itâ€™s just a good thing to do!

post_text:
Tonight at the Murray City School District Board of Education meeting... here are the key highlights:

ğŸ‘‰Board members shared individual thoughts regarding the upcoming school year; Member Johnson shared that High School Activities Association is moving forward with fall sports
ğŸ‘‰Patron statements were shared
ğŸ‘‰Darren Dean requested a few adjustments to the district calendar
ğŸ‘‰Missy Hamilton shared Early Literacy Plan updates
ğŸ‘‰Superintendent Covington introduced and proposed the 2020-21 Board meeting schedule; she also introduced and proposed key elements and protocols of the MCSD reopening plans and Murray Returns with Care initiative
ğŸ‘‰Assistant Superintendent Bushnell introduced and proposed learning choices students will have when school opens, including: (1) In-Class Learning; (2) Directed Online Learning; (3) Independent Online Learning (secondary only); For students choosing in-class learning, MCSD will also offer a Blended Learning Resource should they need to be temporarily absent during the school year.

#wearemurray #murrayreturnswithcare

post_text:
WHAT'S TODAYğŸ“†
Today is National Eat Your Beans Day. When was the last meal you included beans?

ğŸ‘‰Fun Fact About Chickpeas: Also known as garbanzo beans, these legumes pack a whopping 12.5 grams of fiber, 71 % of the recommended daily intake (RDI) of folate, 84% RDI of Manganese, and 26% RDI of Iron per serving in 1 cup. Add chickpeas to stews like you would any bean. However, they also roast nicely with your favorite herbs and spices for a delicious and healthy snack.

#wearemurray

ğŸ“†WHAT'S TODAY
Today is National Postage Stamp Day. Ask your kids if they know what a stamp is or how to mail things...ğŸ“¬

ğŸ‘‰Fun Fact: The United States issued its first postage stamp on July 1, 1847. At that time, stamps were not required. A letter could be mailed without a stamp and delivery paid for by the recipient. In 1855, the postage stamp became mandatory.

post_text:
Tonight's MCSD Board Meeting summary...
- Business Manager Richard Reese gave a financial picture that looks very positive, better than expected thanks to the state legislature largely holding public education harmless
- Superintendent Jennifer Covington introduced David Roberts, new director of support services
- No rate increase on foodservice (school lunch and breakfast)
- Board members expressed appreciation to the State Legislature and also district staff for continued work
- Director, Personnel & Student Services Darin Dean shared results of exit and educator engagement surveys conducted
- Director, Elementary Teaching & Learning Missy Hamilton discussed results from Digital Home Learning survey

#wearemurray

post_text:
MCSD is pleased to announce that our free lunch/breakfast service program has been extended through the month of July at ALL 11 serving sites. So this will be lunch and breakfast service, Monday - Friday (no weekend sacks provided).

Through today, we have served more than 45,000 meals since the soft school closure on March 12. And this Summer, since school has been out, we are averaging nearly 1,000 meals per day. Huge shout out to our food service team for making this daily effort to ensure kids are fed and cared for.

#wearemurray

post_text:
This is Murray City School District's (MCSD) annual notice that special education files of students born, in this case 1994, will soon be destroyed. Parents of former MCSD students and former students born that year may claim them if desired, but no later than July 31, 2020.

To claim files, individuals will be required to provide identification confirming their affinity to the records before receiving them. For additional information or to make an appointment to pick up files, call Lisa Adair, MCSD At Risk Programs, at 801-264-7400.

ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰Parents: Chrombebook Reminder/FAQğŸ‘ˆğŸ‘ˆ

Q: SHOULD WE RETURN MY STUDENT'S CHROMEBOOk?ğŸ’»
A: It depends. Students in grades K-11 will keep their Chromebook and bring it with them when they return to school in the fall. This includes students moving from 6th grade to the junior high schools and 9th-grade students moving to Murray High School. If students are NOT returning to MCSD in the fall, their Chromebooks must be returned to the District Office between May 29 and June 4. Call 801-264-7411 to make an appointment for that return. Failure to do so will result in a fine and filed police report.

Q: What if I donâ€™t want to keep the Chromebook over the Summer?ğŸŒ
A: Parents that donâ€™t want to keep their studentâ€™s Chromebook over Summer can call 801-264-7411 to schedule a return appointment on or after May 29.

#wearemurray

post_text:
ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰Parents Reminder: How will Fourth Term be Graded?ğŸ‘ˆğŸ‘ˆ
[If you have questions, please consult with your student's teacher(s)]

Elementary Schools will be issuing grades in either Aspire or Illuminate. Along with report cards issued with pick up appointments on June 1-4, as described below, an explanation of grading will be provided with the report cards. Illuminate schools will be able to see their proficiency (1, 2, 3, 4) for those standards that were covered or an N/A for those standards not taught in Term 4 or an NE for â€œnot enough evidenceâ€ for those standards where a student wasnâ€™t able to provide evidence of mastering the standard.

Secondary Schools will be issuing grades in Aspire. Students will earn a letter grade and can request a P in place of a letter grade. Students who have not completed sufficient work or students receiving an F will receive an Incomplete. Students have until 9/30/20 to work with teachers to change Incompletes to a P.

There will be no citizenship grades for students in grades K-12.

shared_text:
Murray High School Instrumental Music
May 27 at 6:53 PM Â·

We're very happy to announce that clinics and auditions for the 2020-21 Murray Spartans Marching Percussion section will be held on June 11, 12, & 13. Times and details can be found in the packet that is linked below. Anyone is welcome to audition for the section regardless of instrument or musical background. The clinics are meant to help prepare students to be ready for the auditions. Mrs. Beckstrand returns as our Percussion Instructor this year and will continue to develop one of the outstanding marching percussion sections in the state. Come join us and see what makes the Murray Spartan Marching Band the current Region 6 champions!

Information Packet - https://drive.google.com/open?id=1HFioIwTBmxHFCcTzXvBhwQSQ2MOc1E6L

Audition time sign-up - https://www.signupgenius.com/go/70A0E4BA5A72FA5F85-marching

Shout out to the girls in our Murray Cyber Club who qualified for and participated in the Girls Go Cyberstart national tournament last week, and their advisor Natalie Watts.

Girls Go Cyberstart is a program where students can compete in a series of digital games and puzzles focused on teaching cyber security. This program will no doubt provide valuable experience thinking through real world cyber security problems that will lead to great career opportunities.

post_text:
Mike Okumura, Longview Elementary teacher and Corey Peterson, McMillan Elementary librarian, have been chosen as Utah PTA Outstanding Educator and Support Staff winners for 2020.

Each year Utah PTA accepts nominations across the state for outstanding individuals working among nine different categories of public elementary and secondary education. Depending on status of public gatherings an event is held in honor of the recipients in the Fall of each year.

post_text:
Kelli Sevey Kercher, director of At-Risk Programs at Murray City School District received the University of Utah's 2019-20 College of Education, Department of Special Education, Outstanding Alumna Award this week. Each year, this award recognizes two distinguished graduates of Utah's program. Kelli has been with MCSD since 1990 and has made invaluable contributions in areas of special education, developing programs of service that have touched the lives of many successful students.

"Kelli is a dedicated professional who wears many hats in her role as Director of At-Risk Programs for Murray City School District. She is an advocate for our students with special needs and works diligently to plan, administer, and assess both short and long-term services for them. She has a strong leadership background and a wealth of experience as a special education teacher. We are fortunate to have her skills in supporting our students." - Superintendent Jennifer Covington.

#wearemurray

post_text:
Murray High School's Noah Hardman shared this in Career and Technical Education's (CTE) newsletter this month. Also a recipient of the 2020 CTE Scholarship and Tuition Award, Noah has been involved in this project pictured where he and other students have been building this home over near Wheeler Farm.

â€œMy love of woodworking came from my dad, but it was Mr. Drury, my CTE teacher, that helped me realize that I could take this hobby and turn it into a career. One way he did this was by providing me with the opportunity to work on building our speck house. Seeing my hobby in a much grander scale, and practical application, made me look at things in a completely different light.â€

#wearemurray #wefinishstrong

As Parkside students have demonstrated there are lots of simple ways we can work together to support one another during times of crisis. Healthcare workers and isolated patients need to know we support them and are rooting for their success.

Parkside Elementary students created cards of support and encouragement for Intermountain Medical Center (IMC) healthcare workers. Today, Principal Brian Dawes and Vice-Principal Kay Oborn presented them to IMC's Suzanne Anderson, Nurse Administrator, and Kris Beldrin, Communications.

One of the casualties of our Spring social distancing directives was the MCSD 2020 Pinnacle Awards banquet ğŸ˜¢ğŸ˜¢ğŸ˜¢. Each year Murray Education Foundation honors a class of nominated teachers, personnel, and volunteers for their outstanding service to students and staff of MCSD. While the banquet is still hoped for in the Fall, the MEF Committee decided to get out and present the gift baskets of donated goods at the doorsteps of recipients last week.ğŸ†ğŸ†ğŸ†

ğŸ‘‰So, we honor the following 2020 recipients:ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘

- Sheri Heaton, Teacher, Longview Elementary School
- Lisa White, Teacher, Murray High School
- Ryan Moffett, Teacher, Murray High School
- Randy Bodily, Teacher, Riverview Junior High School
- Ginger Shaw, Teacher, Grant Elementary School
- Sheri Winn, Teacher, McMillan Elementary School
- Monica Giles, Volunteer, Riverview Junior High School
- Brady Nielsen, Technology Specialist, School District Office

#wearemurray #wefinishstrong ğŸ’ª

All indications from the Governorâ€™s office and State Health Department are positive right now, affirming our efforts to â€˜stay safe and stay homeâ€™ have helped â€˜flatten the curveâ€™ of COVID-19 in Utah. While we are not out of the woods yet, the Governor has moved the state to â€˜moderate riskâ€™ status which signals a return to some basic functions and services in most sectors of our economy. As indicated below, we are likewise cautiously adjusting some of our policies to expand our availability to parents and students. We have complete faith in our Murray community, that we will work together and do our part as citizens.

post_text:
In the days and weeks ahead, we will be providing important information and details about the final days and weeks of the school year. As you can appreciate, there are lots of plans and contingencies we are developing each day to address the issues below, and more. The most important message we want to convey, however, is that we intend to finish the year strong, with dignity, and respect for all. We encourage you to join us in that effort so that we can show our students, community, and entire state that #wearemurray and #wefinishstrong.

Todayâ€™s update covers a number of different FAQs:
- When the school year will end and final week plans
- 4th Term Grades and Distribution
- Returning District Property, Fines, Yearbooks
- Chromebook Returns, Damage, and Summer Use
- Honoring Graduates
- Summer Math Acceleration Program
- 5th Grade Maturation Program

Go here for the full update: https://bit.ly/MCSDApr23

post_text:
RESOLVED - PLEASE SEE COMMENTS.

Parents - we are currently receiving reports from within our district and from other districts around the country that several online hosted applications are not working properly this morning.

Here is a list of known malfunctioning applications:
- Seesaw
- ClassKick
- Zearn
- Lexia
- Google Docs
- Forms
- PDF's
- YouTube on Chromebooks (works on PCs and mobile devices)

We have also received word that this is affecting assignments and content turned in earlier this week. Thank you for your patience as we work to better understand the nature of these issues and when they will be back up and running.

post_text:
Show your support for Murray High Seniors by adding a Frame to your Facebook profile picture! Here's how:
1. Hover over your Facebook profile picture and click UPDATE
2. Click ADD FRAME
3. In the search bar at the top, type MURRAY HIGH SCHOOL
4. Select the one that looks like this picture
5. Click USE AS PROFILE PICTURE.

There is also an option to select for how long you want it to remain.

post_text: Governor Herbert and State Superintendent Dickson announced today that all schools will continue digital home learning for the remainder of the scheduled school year. Murray City School District knows this brings up many questions and concerns for students, parents, and our community. District and school leaders have been discussing contingency plans for this scenario. Information will be shared with all stakeholders next week. We ask for your patience as we continue to work through a myriad of details and considerations in finishing the year with digital home learning.
text: Governor Herbert and State Superintendent Dickson announced today that all schools will continue digital home learning for the remainder of the scheduled school year. Murray City School District knows this brings up many questions and concerns for students, parents, and our community. District and school leaders have been discussing contingency plans for this scenario. Information will be shared with all stakeholders next week. We ask for your patience as we continue to work through a myriad of details and considerations in finishing the year with digital home learning.

shared_text:

MCSD Briefing for Wednesday, April 8.

We made it through Wednesday! Todayâ€™s update is fairly short and sweet and all about CARE!

In life we care about lots of things, but too often we forget to care for ourselves. This moment in history is challenging in so many different ways and many of you are working so hard to give and serve one another - we see that reflected daily. Sometimes itâ€™s heroic and other times just kindness. But please carve out a little bit of time to care for yourself each day so that you can go on being heroic and kind in other parts of the day.

Todayâ€™s Update:
- Chromebook Care
- Self Care and Resources Reminder
- Kindergarten Registration (including TBEK)

post_text:
In keeping with Salt Lake County Mayor Jenny Wilsonâ€™s public health order issued Sunday, March 30, Murray City School District is restricting the use of all playgrounds, courts, fields, and pavilions. Open access outdoor fields and facilities will remain open for individuals or those residing within in the same household. We have a number of schools that are co-located with these amenities so we appreciate your support in this.

If you spot activity that is out of compliance with the Countyâ€™s order, such as pickup games, activities involving groups, or general gatherings of children or adults on District property, please notify the District Office at (801) 264-7400 or by email at info@murrayschools.org

The County has stated that residents may enjoy outdoor activities but must do so responsibly, maintaining a social distance from people outside of their household. We recognize this represents another challenge in the COVID-19 issue. However, we also need to ensure the safety of our communities and a quicker resolution to the current crisis.

#wearemurray #wegotthis

Region 19 PTA would like to invite all Murray City School District students to begin working on their Reflections entries for the 2020-2021 school year!

With our digital learning time and Spring Break, this is a great opportunity to start. The theme is "I Matter Because.....". Categories are Visual Arts (2D & 3D), photography, film, music, dance, literature and music.

[Rules can be found at utahpta.org under the Programs tab].
Happy Creating! If you have questions, email region19@utahpta.org.

MCSD Daily Briefing for Friday, March 20...

As we wrap up an unusual and historical week in education for MCSD, Utah, and the Nation, please know we appreciate your patience and determination. We are seeing many, many examples of digital home learning working really well. There are issues, but we continue to iron them out each day - the future is bright! We wish everyone a healthy and happy weekend!

MCSD Daily Briefing for Thursday, March 19...

Today we want to continue to emphasize the importance of patience, resilience, and positivity. As adjustments and disruptions in this new reality happen, heightened concerns and fears will follow. However, we continue to be amazed and proud of our Murray community.

Please ensure you are taking time to self-care as parents and students - this is all unprecedented and can be overwhelming. But we are going to rise above this together. Weâ€™re going to learn and grow together. We got this! We are Murray!

post_text:
Parents and students: We are getting reports of power outages in Salt Lake County today following the earthquake. As such, we will NOT be holding online learning today. We will also not be able to offer lunch service today as there are potential aftershocks and weâ€™ll need time to assess damage at our schools and the safety of our employees. We will keep you posted throughout the day as further decisions and information are available.

Also, the District Office is closed today.

post_text:
Today's District Update (Saturday, March 14)...

As you can see from the photo album... District officials have been working remotely today, but in communication with one another throughout the day to further discuss and refine the structure and framework of our Digital Home Learning efforts.

Another big thank you to everyone for your efforts during this time of school dismissal, we've had lots of excellent, constructive feedback from parents, students, and teachers that has been positive and useful - keep it up!

We will be communicating more instructions to parents on Monday regarding internet access, material pickup, and other support-related details.
#wearemurray #digitalhomelearning

post_text: Shout out to Comcast!
shared_text:
INTERNETESSENTIALS.COM
Internet Essentials from Comcast

Joseph Silverzweig shared a link to the group: Murray Citizens.
March 13 at 5:15 PM Â·

I wanted to provide some information about internet connectivity for folks whose kids are having to study at home and don't have wifi for their homes. I'm part of Comcast's executive leadership team here in Utah, managing our relationships with local governments and community partners.

1. Comcast is opening their public hot spots across the entire country.
2. Comcast is removing all data caps for residential users for the next 60 days.
3. Comcast is not terminating service for anyone or charging late or disconnect fees for the next 60 days.

We also have Internet Essentials, which is $9.95 a month, high speed internet for anyone who qualifies for federal assistance. In response to covid-19, we have increased our speeds to 25/3 and are giving 60 days of free service for all our new customers.

If you have any questions, please ask me here or send me a PM. If you work with a community group who has a need for this, we can talk about ways that we can get the message out to your clients.

post_text:
A special thank you to parents, students, teachers, and staff of the Murray City School District (MCSD). We have noted the outpouring of your support in our decision to close MCSD out of concerns related to COVID-19. We recognize this effort is ongoing and we ask for your patience as we now work through the details.

Communication is important so we will be providing daily updates on our website, social media, and parent email system with information to keep you in the loop on our plans. If you have questions, please call the District Office at 801-264-7400 or contact us by email at info@murrayschools.org

Go here to see our update as of 5:00 pm today:
https://www.murrayschools.org/daily-mcsd-closure-updates/

post_text:
Murray City School District (MCSD) continues to proactively seek solutions to ensure a continued, meaningful academic experience in the event schools must close for any reason. As such, MCSD teachers and administrators have developed a Digital Home Learning Day Plan to help bridge unexpected interruptions of normal school operations.

To put this plan into practice, the MCSD Teaching and Learning Team has approved a test run of a Digital Home Learning Day on March 27. This day has the support of the Murray School District Board of Education and the Utah State School Superintendent. As you may recall, March 27 was originally set aside as a â€œSnow Makeupâ€ day for the District, and specifically to make up our February 3 snow day closure.

Go here to read more: https://www.murrayschools.org/district-announces-digital-learning-day-march-27/

#wearemurray #digitalhomelearningday

post_text:
Today is National Grammar Day... here are some fun facts:

1. â€œI amâ€ is the shortest complete sentence in the English language.

2. A pangram sentence is one that contains every letter in the alphabet. (For example: â€œThe quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dogâ€)

3. Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious (*breath*) is NOT the longest word in English, it's actually pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis (good luck)

4. The shortest, oldest, and most commonly used word is â€œI.â€

5. A new word is added to the dictionary every two hours.

6. Crutch words are those we repeat often. For example, "like" - "Like I was watching this show, and like the room was like silent."

7. "Swims" still reads like "swims" when turned upside down - words like this are called ambigrams.

8. Girl used to mean small boy or girl. It used to mean â€œchildâ€ or â€œyoung personâ€ regardless of the gender.

#wearemurray #nationalgrammarday

post_text:
Parents: Please be aware that Murray City School District (MCSD) is actively preparing an Infectious Disease Outbreak Response Plan to address any potential outbreak of COVID-19, also called Novel Coronavirus.

In matters of public health, MCSD works closely with the Utah Department of Health and the Salt Lake County Health Department for guidance. But we also want to partner with YOU. The health and safety of district students and personnel is serious and there are things we can all do to make a difference. Linked below are some guidelines and tips to ensuring all students and staff are protected.

Finally, as part of our district plan, the district teaching and learning team are making preparations for online learning so that learning can continue in the event of a school closure. Principals are discussing the logistics of this plan with teachers at their school. More information will be shared about this in the days ahead.
#wearemurray #preparedness

Go here to read more about what YOU can do: https://www.murrayschools.org/district-update-on-coronavirus-response-plan-and-tips/

post_text:
From the Center for Disease Control:
"Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing."

Why? Viruses can spread from person to person via respiratory droplets. When an infected person coughs or sneezes, close contacts can be infected. In addition, the virus can end up on doorknobs, elevator buttons and other surfaces. If you touch those surfaces and then touch your eyes, nose or mouth, you can become infected.

#wearemurray #handwashing

Today is Read Across America Day, in honor of the late great Dr. Seuss's (Theodor Seuss Geisel) birthday. What is your favorite Dr. Seuss book?

Ever wonder how they rank in terms of gross sales all time? Here you go:
1. Green Eggs and Ham (1960)
2. One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish (1960)
3. The Cat in the Hat (1957)
4. ABC: An Amazing Alphabet Book (1963)
5. Oh, The Places You'll Go! (1990)

"Teachers are willing to take risks with technology in the classroom, willing to learn from trial and error, and share ideas with each other. In our experience with other districts, Murray teachers have embraced technology quickly and effectively to help students succeed in a digital world." - Lynn Gutzwiller and Geri Smith, MCSD Technology and Instructional Coaches.

post_text:
BREAKING NEWS... The Utah PTA just announced the winners of the Reflections Competition and Murray was well represented among the top entries. In fact, Hillcrest Jr. High school's Leif Larson is heading to nationals in the Film competition.

Leif also received an award of Merit in Photography, as did
Katie Sandberg (Murray High School) in Literature and
Thomas Fetzer (Murray High School) in 2D Visual Arts.

Congratulations to all who participated! Murray City School District is proud of you for your hard work and efforts!

FYI: Reflections is a National PTA program that recognizes outstanding student achievement in visual arts, literature, musical composition, photography, film production and dance choreography. This is an opportunity for students to unleash their creative talent and bring out the artist in them.

Here's a list of all the winners: https://www.murrayschools.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Middle-High-School-Program-Reflections-State-Winners-2019-2020.pdf

#wearemurray #Utahreflections

post_text:
Happy National Periodic Table Day: On February 7, 1863, English chemist John Newlands published one of the first table of elements, which divided the known 56 elements into 11 groups based on the â€œLaw of Octaves.â€

Arranging the elements according to increasing atomic weight, Newlands was one of the first scientists to detect a pattern to the properties of elements. As a result, his table left room for new discoveries, predicting future discovered elements would complete the table.

www.PeriodicTableDay.org

#wearemurray #periodictableday

post_text:
Based on current weather conditions, Murray City School District will impose a two-hour late start for all schools and facilities today. This means all schools will begin two hours later than normal but end as normally scheduled.

Buses will run their normal routes but two hours later than normal. As always, parents may keep their students at home if they feel conditions are not safe. We encourage our teachers to drive and arrive safe.

Please see our Kindergarten Snow Day Schedule Here: https://www.murrayschools.org/kindergarten-snow-day-schedule/

As forecasts call for snow overnight, we encourage parents to prepare for extra time to get students to school safely tomorrow. We are planning on all schools being open and operating as normal.

MCSD crews will be up early evaluating roads and assessing conditions. If plans change, we will notify parents as soon as possible. We recognize conditions can vary from neighborhood to neighborhood, therefore parents are also reminded that they may keep their students at home anytime they feel it is unsafe for their students to travel to school. #wearemurray #stormpreparation

The Murray City School District is NOT seeing any unusual spikes or upticks in school absences for this time of year. We appreciate the efforts of families, students, teachers, administrators, and staff who follow the adage that â€œan ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.â€

Letâ€™s keep it that wayâ€¦ continue your practices of good hand-washing hygiene. Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth and stay home for at least 24 hours if you have a fever. And health experts say getting a flu shot is still a great first line of defense for those who choose it.

#wearemurray #goodhygienepractices

text:
Congratulations to new Murray City Council members Kat Martinez (Dist. 1), Rosalba Dominguez (Dist. 3), and Brett Hales (Dist. 5). Murray City School District is excited to continue our wonderful partnership with the Mayor, Council, and other community leaders this year.

The swearing-in ceremony featured the Murray High Madrigals, singing our National Anthem, and Murray Police Department handling color guard duties to kick things off.
#utpol #wearemurray

text: January 2020 "Your Murray Schools," also published in the January Murray Journal. HAPPY NEW YEAR & DECADE from your friends in the Murray City School District!

post_text:
McMillan Elementary School Wins National Award! Murray City School District is proud of the National Blue Ribbon School recognition awarded to McMillan Elementary School during this school year.

CONGRATULATIONS to the students, faculty and staff of this outstanding school. What a great accomplishment for this legacy MCSD school to be our very first school in the District to receive this high honor! Mrs. Joy Sanford did an amazing job of guiding the school to become an Exemplary High Performing School in Utah this year.

United States Congressman Ben McAdams visited the school for a special awards assembly to celebrate the schools great accomplishment, and present them with a Congressional Award Recognition. (Representative McAdams is pictured center in the photo.)

post_text:
SIGHTFEST 2020!
The Murray School District is proud to be partnering with Friends for Sight again this year to hold Sightfest 2020. Sightfest is an annual school event that provides free eye exam and glasses to those who qualify.

- Your child qualifies to participate in Sightfest if:
- Your child failed their vision screening AND they do not have medical insurance or Medicaid that covers a vision exam and/or glasses.

Please share this with MCSD parents whom you think may be interested and qualify. If you have questions or concerns, please contact:
Shanda EchoHawk, RN
Murray School District Nurse
801-264-7400 ext. 5050
sechohawk@murrayschools.org

post_text:
AIR QUALITY CONCERNS:
MCSD offices have received questions recently regarding the current air quality issue in our area, and when we keep kids inside rather than sending them outside for recess. Murray City School District follows specific guidelines put out by the Utah Department of Health and the Department of Environmental Air Quality. Here is a copy of the â€œRecess Guidance for Schools" (based on air quality). If parents request their student stay in because of respiratory or other health issues, or if they have a doctor's note, then they should be allowed to stay in and need to make their school office or childâ€™s teacher aware. The guidelines indicate that when the PM (Particulate Matter) goes above the 55.4 mark or 150 AQI (Air Quality Index) levels, then all students will be staying indoors for recess. Schools and the District Office both monitor these conditions.
text:
AIR QUALITY CONCERNS:
MCSD offices have received questions recently regarding the current air quality issue in our area, and when we keep kids inside rather than sending them outside for recess. Murray City School District follows specific guidelines put out by the Utah Department of Health and the Department of Environmental Air Quality. Here is a copy of the â€œRecess Guidance for Schools" (based on air quality). If parents request their student stay in because of respiratory or other health issues, or if they have a doctor's note, then they should be allowed to stay in and need to make their school office or childâ€™s teacher aware. The guidelines indicate that when the PM (Particulate Matter) goes above the 55.4 mark or 150 AQI (Air Quality Index) levels, then all students will be staying indoors for recess. Schools and the District Office both monitor these conditions.

post_text: EDUCATION SUPPORT PROFESSIONALS Day is TODAY, Nov. 20, 2019. Nearly four of every 10 public school employees are Education Support Professionals (ESPs), working together with teachers and administrators to ensure the basic right of every student to attend a great public school. They perform a variety of jobs that promote quality education, foster positive learning environments, offer nutritious meals to ensure students are ready to learn, provide reliable transportation, and maintain safe and clean schools for all students. Thank one of these great MCSD employees TODAY!

2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe at the bus stop:
MOBILE DEVICES
Cell phones and other electronic devices are often permitted on the school bus as long as:
â€¢ They are in backpacks or other holders, keeping hands free to use handrails while boarding and departing the bus.
â€¢ Sound is muted or headphones, ear buds or similar devices are used.
â€¢ Content does not violate the law or school district policy and procedures.
â€¢ Use does not create a distraction for the driver.

post_text:
2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe at the bus stop:
GETTING ON AND OFF THE BUS
â€¢ Warn children that if they drop something getting on and off the bus, they should never pick it up. Instead, they should tell the driver and follow the driverâ€™s instructions.
â€¢ Remind children to look to the right before they step off the bus.
â€¢ If you meet your child at the bus stop after school, wait on the side where the child will be dropped off, not across the street. Children can be so excited to see you after school that
they dash across the street and forget the safety rules.

post_text:
2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe
AT THE BUS STOP:
â€¢ Have children wait in a location where the driver can see them while driving down the street. Try to avoid waiting in a house or car.
â€¢ Do not let children play in the street. Playing with balls or other toys that could roll into the street is also dangerous.
text:
2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe
AT THE BUS STOP:
â€¢ Have children wait in a location where the driver can see them while driving down the street. Try to avoid waiting in a house or car.
â€¢ Do not let children play in the street. Playing with balls or other toys that could roll into the street is also dangerous.

post_text:
2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe at the bus stop:
WALKING TO THE BUS STOP
â€¢ Walk young children to the bus stop or encourage children to walk in groups. There is safety in numbers; groups are easier for drivers to see.
â€¢ Practice good pedestrian behavior: walk on the sidewalk, and if there is no sidewalk stay out of the street. If you must walk in the street, walk single file, face traffic and stay as close to the edge of the road as you can.
â€¢ Stop and look left, right and then left again if you must cross the street. Do the same thing at drive -ways and alleys. Exaggerate your head turns and narrate your actions so your child knows you are looking left, right and left.
text:
2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe at the bus stop:
WALKING TO THE BUS STOP
â€¢ Walk young children to the bus stop or encourage children to walk in groups. There is safety in numbers; groups are easier for drivers to see.
â€¢ Practice good pedestrian behavior: walk on the sidewalk, and if there is no sidewalk stay out of the street. If you must walk in the street, walk single file, face traffic and stay as close to the edge of the road as you can.
â€¢ Stop and look left, right and then left again if you must cross the street. Do the same thing at drive -ways and alleys. Exaggerate your head turns and narrate your actions so your child knows you are looking left, right and left.

post_text:
2019 NATIONAL SCHOOL BUS SAFETY WEEK is Oct. 21-25. This year's theme is "My School Bus, The Safest Form of Student Transportation."

Here are some tips for keeping children safe at the bus stop:
GETTING READY FOR SCHOOL
â€¢ Have your children put everything they carry in a backpack or school bag so that they wonâ€™t drop things along the way.
â€¢ Encourage them to wear bright, contrasting colors so they will be more easily seen by drivers.
â€¢ Make sure children leave home on time so they can arrive at the bus stop before it is due, ideally at least five minutes early. Running after or in front of a bus is dangerous.

Murray City School District was honored with a visit from State Superintendent Sydnee Dickson today, along with Angie Stallings, Deputy Superintendent of Policy at Utah State Board of Education. We appreciated their stopping by several of our schools and the District Office, and were proud to show them the great things going on here in the Murray City School District. WE ... ARE ... MURRAY!
(State Office of Education visitors shown in photo taken at MCSD offices with DO staff members.)

post_text:
Employment Opportunity
TA III Special Ed
Serve as a teaching assistant/para-educator under a Special Education Teacher working with students with a variety of disabilities including mild/moderate, severe, and physical disabilities. Looking for candidates with experience in reading, math, and behavior interventions, tutoring experience, in a teacher prep program at a college, sign language experience (ASL or just survival signs), and/or experience working with students with significant cognitive disabilities.

Part-time hourly positions @ 19 hours per week at the following schools:

Grant Elementary (2 openings)
Liberty Elementary (1 opening)
Longview Elementary (1 opening)
Hillcrest JHS (1 opening)
Murray High School (1 opening)

$14.55 per hour to $16.66 per hour based on experience and education.

Submit a MCSD classified application to:

Murray City School District
Office of Human Resources
5102 S Commerce Drive
Murray UT 84107

For more information on this and other classified positions please visit https://www.murrayschools.org/departments-programs/human-resources/classified/

Employment Opportunity
TA III Special Ed
Serve as a teaching assistant/para-educator under a Special Education Teacher working with students with a variety of disabilities including mild/moderate, severe, and physical disabilities. Looking for candidates with experience in reading, math, and behavior interventions, tutoring experience, in a teacher prep program at a college, sign language experience (ASL or just survival signs), and/or experience working with students with significant cognitive disabilities.

Part-time hourly positions @ 19 hours per week at the following schools:

Grant Elementary (2 openings)
Liberty Elementary (1 opening)
Longview Elementary (1 opening)
Hillcrest JHS (1 opening)
Murray High School (1 opening)

$14.55 per hour to $16.66 per hour based on experience and education.

Submit a MCSD classified application to:

Murray City School District
Office of Human Resources
5102 S Commerce Drive
Murray UT 84107

For more information on this and other classified positions please visit https://www.murrayschools.org/departments-programs/human-resources/classified/

*Please share!
Welcome to the 2019-2020 school year! We encourage you and your preschool-aged child to drop by our Early Childhood Education Center at 73 W. 6100 S. to inquire about class availability or to register onsite.

Contact ECEC Coordinator Kaydee Fondaco if you have any questions; email kfondaco@murrayschools.org or call the ECEC office at 801-264-7404.

The ECEC Back to School Open House will be August 28, 2019 from 9:00-10:30 AM; and 6:00-7:30 PM.
The first day of school will be September 3 or 4, based on your enrolled class day. The ECEC 2019-2020 Calendar will be available soon.

See the ECEC page on the MCSD website for links regarding the handbook and policies.

post_text: Educators from McMillan Elementary were invited to participate in a summer Literacy Summit with ULEAD (Utah Leading Through Effective, Actionable, and Dynamic Education). McMillan Principal Joy Sanford is pictured 2nd from right with her team. The group shared successful practices relative to evidence-based practices and worked collaboratively with other participants to help inform and support colleagues from across the state. Their combined work and feedback will be published in the form of actionable practices and support materials to improve the early literacy outcomes for students throughout Utah!
text: Educators from McMillan Elementary were invited to participate in a summer Literacy Summit with ULEAD (Utah Leading Through Effective, Actionable, and Dynamic Education). McMillan Principal Joy Sanford is pictured 2nd from right with her team. The group shared successful practices relative to evidence-based practices and worked collaboratively with other participants to help inform and support colleagues from across the state. Their combined work and feedback will be published in the form of actionable practices and support materials to improve the early literacy outcomes for students throughout Utah!

post_text:
Murray High To Distribute Cumulative Folders:
Murray High class of 2016 cumulative folders are ready to release. The folders contain immunization records, grades, some testing results and other misc. information. They will be available until June 17, 2019 in the high school counseling center. Files will be destroyed after Monday, June 17, 2019.
Anyone interested in picking up his or her cumulative folder will need to have proper identification. If a parent wants to pick up the file, a letter of permission from the student with their birth date and contact information is required along with proper identification.
If you need more information, contact Karen Winther, MHS Registrar at 801-264-7460 ext 5171, email kwinther@murrayschools.org
text:

Anyone interested in picking up his or her cumulative folder will need to have proper identification. If a parent wants to pick up the file, a letter of permission from the student with their birth date and contact information is required along with proper identification.
If you need more information, contact Karen Winther, MHS Registrar at 801-264-7460 ext 5171, email kwinther@murrayschools.org

post_text: Newly organized Murray High Alumni Association (MHAA) awarded their 1st scholarship ever to Asheby Kearns at Murray High Scholarship Night. Congrats, Asheby, and thanks to MHAA for your hard work in organizing this great group to provide support of Murray High and assistance to our great alumni! Pictured with Asheby is MHAA chairman and founder Spencer Olsen , MHS Class of 2009. To find out more about the Murray High Alumni Association, go to https://murrayhighalumni.org/
shared_text:
Murray High Alumni Association
May 27, 2019 at 3:32 PM Â·

We are proud to have given our first scholarship this past week at the High School's Scholarship and Awards night to a very deserving senior, Asheby Kearns. Congratulations Asheby! Asheby plans to attend SLCC this fall and prepare to become a police officer. She has an incredible academic and extracurricular resume and is poised to do great things.

Thank you to the donors and volunteers who helped ensure this first scholarship was possible. We look forward to giving many more!

If you are interested in volunteering or donating, head over to our website (https://murrayhighalumni.org/initiatives/scholarships/) to learn more!

post_text: Murray ECEC (Early Childhood Education Center) has openings for pre-school Summer Adventure Camps and the Kindergarten Readiness Program. There are three (3) different sessions of each of these programs. Tuition for each session is in the $50 range and classes run four days per session. Sign up right away if you are interested; classes usually fill up . Call 801-264-7404, or email kfondaco@murrayschools.org . Please share this information with anyone who may be interested.

Are you planning your Murray High School class reunion? The newly formed Murray High Alumni Association (MHAA) may be able to help you! Go to the link below and take a look at at their website. They are making great plans to share upcoming reunion plans, support alumni, and provide scholarships for graduating seniors. They also welcome interested alumni to participate and join them in in their mission of "Preserving the Spartan spirit and giving back to deserving students"!

Get the Latest News & Updates:
Follow MSAA on Facebook or Instagram for the latest news and updates. You can also subscribe through the MSAA website and get occasional emails regarding the latest in Murray Alumni news and events.

JAMES COLLINGS - Valedictorian
AMY HARVEY - Salutatorian

Be sure to share congrats with these great kids if you see them! James mom Melanie is also a Murray High School graduate, and his grandmother Judy McArthur worked for many years at Murray High School and is now a volunteer board member on the school Renaissance Association.

JOB OPPORTUNITY: MCSD is in need of a staff LPN Nurse. This is full-time hourly position based on working 180 school days, with health insurance (Select Health), and retirement benefits through Utah Retirement Systems (URS). Candidate must have LPN or RN license. If you or anyone you know might be interested, please go to this link, or call MCSD Offices at 801-264-7400.
https://www.murrayschools.org/departments-programs/human-resources/classified/

FOR PARENTS OF INCOMING MCSD KINDERGARTEN STUDENTS: This year, we are introducing a Tuition Based Extended Kindergarten (TBEK) option for those incoming kindergarten parents who are interested in Tuition Based Extended Kindergarten to be located at Viewmont or Longview elementary schools in the 2019-2020 school year. Here is more information and a link through which you may your express interest in our Tuition Based Extended Kindergarten program.

For any questions or clarifications, please contact the Murray City School District TBEK TEAM at tbek@murrayschools.org

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSer7jYNmvNGkn8z04ORtTEqyjQ_pDnR-k-3MWFToI4kibLAVw/viewform

Thank you for your interest!

DON'T FORGET!
Friday, March 22, 2019 is our MCSD
SNOW DAY MAKE-UP DAY:

This will be a student early dismissal day so that we may have a Â½ day Teacher Work Day. Due to our Snow Day Make-Up day, the previously scheduled APRIL 29, 2019 LATE START DAY will now be a REGULAR SCHOOL DAY.

All schools will begin and buses run at regularly scheduled times. Here is a breakdown of the schedule:

- MURRAY HIGH SCHOOL will dismiss at 12:00 NOON.

- JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOLS (both) will dismiss at 12:10 PM.

- ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS (all) will dismiss at 1:00 PM for grades 1-6. Kindergarten schedules will be posted by each school principal.

* Check with your school office staff for additional questions. There will be NO MORE LATE START DAYS* in the Murray City School District for the 2018-2019 school year.
https://www.murrayschools.org/snow-day-schedule-important-calendar-updates/

post_text:
VIEWMONT ELEMENTARY SCHOOL had a number of students place in the Top 5 at the Utah Science and Engineering Fair (USEF) last week, with with results announced on Friday evening. CONGRATULATIONS to the following students:

Engineering: Mechanical - 1st PLACE
Alex Beckstead & David Larsen

Energy: Chemical and Physical - 3rd Place
Bentley McLaws & Ashton Hansen

Engineering: Materials and Biomedical - 4th Place Annabelle Smith

Principal Jenn King and her staff send out congratulations to not only these 5 students, but to all of the students who participated in this year's USEF school and district level fairs adding, "We could not be more proud of these students!" As one of the parents said, "VIewmont rocked it!"

Thank you's go out to Viewmont's outstanding Science Fair parent volunteers, Theresa Koontz and Brittney Roller, and also to their great teachers!
https://usef.utah.edu/about-us

This year, Hillcrest Jr High School presents it's 20th anniversary musical production: Disney's High School Musical. The show will play March 13-16 at 7 PM. Come celebrate 20 years of musical theatre magic as a large cast of talented students bring Disney's smash hit movie to life!

Tickets are $5 and may be purchased at the door or online at https://hjhweb.murrayschools.org.

post_text: GRANT ELEMENTARY SCHOOL had a wonderful time celebrating National Random Acts of Kindness week towards the end of February. At the school, there were hundreds of acts of kindness happening, an essay and poster contest. The paper chain in the foyer documented all of the acts of kindness that were noticed by adults in the building. On the last day of the week-long event, all teachers wore their kindness shirts which read, â€œIn a world where you can be anything, be kind.â€
